I would really hate a true upper limit of 10,000. With porting my softfp library to CBA C (which is an Assembler and Very Minimal C Compiler), some of the things that need to be done to simply add 2 floating point numbers will quickly exceed 10k with just a few commands (esp with the fact that a memory lookup needs to take place, which is absolutely disgusting without some sort of proper variable system).  This is a huge barrier (and I can't even sync, which tells it to wait until the next game tick, or I risk breaking the in-operation atomacy that the library guarantees). I don't even want to think about how many commands are in a simple USRH operation. I think removing the upper limit entirely is a good idea, so that server operators can set an arbitrary amount of commands to run. Esp when you have really stupid functions like exp(x). (e^x = 1 + x + (x^2)/2 + (x^3)/6 + (x^4)/24 + (x^5)/120 + ... + (x^n)/n! for lim[n->∞]). Even going up to n=7 (where the function converges close enough to e^x to be valid for IEEE754), that is 9 additions, and 7 pow/fact operations (my way of optimizing taylor series to not compute an O(n) recursive function twice). 

I highly doubt I could run more than 1 exp(x) calls in the same tick without crashing right through the 10k upper limit.
No limit would be nice for setting up loops without a repeating command block by just having a a function call for a function that calls for it. It would make things just that much cleaner.

(Im talking about Bedrock edition here)

This would me INSANE for making add-ons, you could have a function repeat without a command block hidden in a random place repeatedly running it.

 

you could  have many add-ons, that need to repeatedly check if a player is using an item or wearing armor, and executing actions (eg. giving player regeneration) on a world, running at the same time.

this would also help for not having to use player.json to run an animation that will then run something, which would help remove compatibility issues between diffrent add-ons.
Thats a very good idea! I can really understand what pain it is always clicking on the noteblock. I'm doing a lot of note block songs myself too.

Don't revert it. Block states are much more elegant and efficient than block entities.

If you want to have a note block item that always places a note block with a specific pitch, use this:

/give @s minecraft:note_block{BlockStateTag:{note:15}}

Here's a graphic for the number you need to set the block state value of "note" to in order to get a specific note:

https://minecraft.gamepedia.com/File:Noteblock_reference.png
yes! devs. get your fingers out of your ears and fix this stuff! we dont need more stuff yet when theres massive problems with parity and change of life fixes!

I disagree that the default entity names ("Zombie", "Shulker", etc.) should be shown instead of the UUIDs, but custom entity names should absolutely be shown! So, in my mind, this is how it would work:

  • If the entity does not have a custom name set, display UUID
  • If the entity has a custom name set, display the custom name
  • For setting/changing entity scoreboard values, you would still have to use the UUID, which would be easier to see if the /scoreboard players get * <objective> worked
or in other words, treat strings as character arrays
And if you could have a gamerule for only allowing spectators to spectate team members

If you mean the changes to commands prior to 1.13, this will not happen. I believe the changes made were beneficial to the command structure, and the new command parser is much more efficient. It's not too difficult to learn the new syntax, if you have you would know how much better it is.

"better" no, just no; 1.13+ commands are way more optimized, less ambiguous and allow for so much more than 1.12's commands; and 1.12's is only easier if you don't bother to learn the 1.13 way, it's actually not harder at all.

I love the idea of a /drop command but there should be a way to choose the coordinates of where to drop the items like this:

/drop @(entity) Minecraft: (item) <x y z>
Oh! And you could do /drop @entity all and it would drop all your items on the ground
Definitely.

It would be nice to have more customization related to player abilities, since we are restricted by what game modes currently allow. I fully support this addition.

As you said, the command could be refined and improved. Each of these abilities could be granted or revoked to a player, regardless of game mode:

  • Creative inventory with Pick Block for any block
  • Usage of blocks, tools, and consumables without damage or consumption
  • Restricted block destruction and placement
  • Instant block destruction without drops
  • Invulnerability
  • Flight with collision
  • Flight without collision
  • Extended interaction range (might be better suited to /attribute)
  • Invisibility to non-spectators
